Award.AwardTitle: IceCube Tau and Cascade Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory is the largest neutrino detector in the world, instrumenting one cubic kilometer of ice near the geographic South Pole. IceCube completed construction in 2011 and includes a densely instrumented 'DeepCore' component in the center of the detector. The goal of IceCube is to detect neutrinos at Teraelectronvolt (TeV) - Petaelectronvolt (PeV) energies from astrophysical accelerators which are thought to be the sources of the highest energy cosmic rays. DeepCore extends IceCube's energy reach down to 10 GeV in order to study phenomena such as atmospheric neutrino oscillations and neutrinos from the annihilation of dark matter in the Galactic Center.

This award will fund the University of Alabama (UA) group that has developed algorithms for detecting tau neutrinos in the waveforms of individual IceCube sensors, lowering the energy threshold for tau detection in order to increase sensitivity to astrophysical taus. Initial analysis of the first year of full detector data has already revealed hints of diffuse neutrino flux in excess of the expected atmospheric background in the 100 TeV - 1 PeV energy range, and the algorithms developed at UA for tau neutrino detection are especially well suited to this energy range.

Broader Impacts: UA has a strong commitment to secondary and undergraduate education. The PI has worked with undergraduates from various departments both in research and in developing outreach activities for local high schools. She also co-hosts a monthly gathering of female physics and engineering undergraduates and participates in public outreach activities that highlight IceCube's unique location and science goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory, in operation since 2011, is the largest neutrino detector in the world. Neutrinos are the lightest known particles and do not interact readily with matter; this makes them difficult to detect, but also means that they have the potential to carry information from deep inside extreme astrophysical events such as the explosions of massive stars, the merging of ultra-dense neutron stars and the activity of supermassive black holes in the centers of galaxies. In 2013, IceCube reported the detection of high energy neutrinos from outside our solar system; the source of these neutrinos is as yet unknown.

One property of the observed high energy neutrino flux which is still under investigation is the proportion of each type (or "flavor") of neutrino observed. According to the current state of knowledge of the properties of neutrinos, we expect to observe equal numbers of the three flavors of neutrinos: electron, muon and tau. Muon neutrinos are easily distinguished by the long trails of light (called "tracks") which they leave in the detector, but both electron and tau neutrinos can produce spherical light patterns (called "cascades") which can be difficult to distinguish except at high energies, where taus will produce a double cascade signature. Unlike the other two flavors of neutrinos, taus are not produced in appreciable numbers by cosmic rays interacting with the Earth's atmosphere, so the observation of taus would both confirm the astrophysical origin of the high energy neutrinos observed by IceCube and also reveal the physics of neutrino interactions in astrophysical environments.

This project has attempted to find the tau double cascade signature by looking at the signal on individual IceCube modules. This so called "double pulse" search, completed as dissertation work under this award, returned null results, but was the first IceCube search to be more sensitive to tau neutrinos than to any other flavor. The work was published in a refereed journal, and further searches and refinements of the double pulse method are ongoing.

This project also supported a dissertation examining the possibility that the IceCube high energy neutrinos arise from the decay of high energy long-lived dark matter particles. An indicator of dark matter origin would be observing an excess of neutrinos at a single energy. The analysis set a limit on the decay lifetime of dark matter particles called gravitinos, and further analyses are ongoing to increase the sensitivity of this search.

In the area of public outreach, the PI has organized an IceCube masterclass at the University of Alabama in order to educate local high school students about the field of particle astrophysics. The PI has also prepared cloud chamber kits for use by high school classrooms, and has given public lectures for retirees, the general public, and female STEM major undergraduates.
